elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-TITLES. SCENE 0. INT. RADIO ROOM.
SCENE IS ALL A PREVIEW OF MATERIAL FROM SCENE 78.
IS TRAPPED IN A BURNING ROOM. SHE BANGS ON A LOCKED WINDOW WITH HER PALMS.
(COUGHING FROM SMOKE) Help! Please! Somebody help me! Help! (WEAKENING) Doctor. Where are you? I know you’re out there. So where are you? Where are you! (SHE COUGHS, COLLAPSES AND DIES
APPROX 10 SECONDS)
FX: AS SHE COUGHS AND DIES, THE SOUNDS OF FLAMES ARE
BY THE SOUND OF STATIC RADIO INTERFERENCE GROWING LOUDER AND LOUDER (THINK ‘I WANT YOU’ BY THE BEATLES, OR ‘I
YOU’ BY DEPECHE MODE) UNTIL ALL OTHER SOUND IS LOST. THEN CUT SHARPLY, A MOMENT’S SILENCE, THEN -
MUSIC: OPENING THEME.
SCENE 1. INT. CAR.
FX: A 1970s CAR MAKING ITS WAY DOWN A MUDDY, BUMPY COUNTRY LANE
AT 17MPH. RAINING HEAVILY. WINDSCREEN WIPERS SQUEAKING.
THE RADIO PLAYS SOMETHING 1979-ISH. BLONDIE— OR POLICE-LIKE. BUT THE TUNING GOES AWRY, WITH INCREASING INTERFERENCE UNTIL THERE IS JUST STATIC.
Oh, give up, Andy.
Must be the weather.
FX: HE SWITCHES THE RADIO OFF.
Are you sure this is it?
(DRIVING) You’re the one with the map.
For all we know this way just leads to a farm or something. We should turn back, ask someone at that pub we went past.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL)
That was two miles ago.
Exactly. We should’ve got there by now.
FX: ANDY CRUNCHES DOWN A GEAR.
(EFFORT OF MANUAL GEAR CHANGE) “The first past the church.”
Maybe they meant another turning, this is muddy track.
Page 4
turning on the right,
barely more than a
Well, you can give it a rest, ‘cos we’re here. Look.
FX: JOANNA FOLDS UP MAP.
That’s it? Half a dozen caravans in a field? Oh, great idea
Andy, let’s go on holiday in the Somme!
Hold up, granddad’s coming to say hello.
FX: CAR COMES TO A HALT.
Coming to tell us the campsite’s closed, I hope.
FX: TAP ON WINDOW. ANDY WINDS IT DOWN. PERCY LEANS IN.
Can I help you, son?
Hi. Andy Clover. I’ve booked a caravan here, I spoke to a
Mister Rossiter on the phone.
Course you did. Mister Clover, yes. And...?
This is my wife, Joanna. Clover.
You’re in number four, over by the corner.
PEERS IN
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 5
Cheers. I don’t suppose you’d -
Don’t worry, son, I’ll open the gate.
Thanks. (FX: WINDS UP WINDOW. TAP ON WINDOW. HE WINDS IT DOWN) Sorry, what is it?
Your key. (FX: KEYRING JANGLE)
(TAKES KEY) Right, yeah. Wouldn’t get very far without that.
No, you wouldn’t.
FX: ANDY WINDS UP WINDOW.
Woah, somebody got up on the wrong side of bed.
How would you like to be stuck out in this weather?
Not much. But that seems to be the plan for the next week.
FX: ANDY PUTS CAR INTO GEAR, THEY DRIVE INTO FIELD OVER BUMPS.
(UNDER HIS BREATH) Well, this is gonna be a laugh a minute.
And what was all that about me being your wife?
You know what these country folks are like, he might not approve.
What? He’d turn us away for being an unmarried couple daring to share the same caravan? What is this, the middle ages?
(TO HIMSELF) Middle of nowhere, next best thing...
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 6
2. INT. CARAVAN.
FX: DOOR UNLOCKED, DOOR OPENS. RAINING OUTSIDE AND ON SKYLIGHT.
JOANNA AND ANDY CLAMBER IN. IT IS VERY CRAMPED, EVERY MOVEMENT MAKES A SQUEAK OR CREAK.
Oh good grief, there’s not room to swing a cat. And it’s freezing!
FX: THEY CLOSE DOOR. ANDY MOVES TO OTHER END, OPENING AND
CUPBOARDS.
Give me a second... (FINDS IT) Ah-ha. Gas heater.
FX: JOANNA SITS IN THE SEATING AREA NEAR US.
Try not to blow us up.
FX: TRYING TO LIGHT IT) Come on, come on. (FX: IT LIGHTS
There, genius. Soon have us warmed up.
And then what?
It can’t rain forever. And then we can go for a walk, get some fresh country air.
And pneumonia too, while we’re at it. It’s nearly sunset.
FX: SINISTER KNOCK ON DOOR. ANDY OPENS IT.
Making yourselves at home?
Yeah, something like that. Come in, mate.
FX: HE CLOSES DOOR BEHIND HIM.
I see you’ve found the heater. Give me a moment, I’1ll light the
lamps.
There’s no electricity?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 7
FX: HE LIGHTS A LAMP — MATCHES, HISS OF GAS, ‘POP’ OF LIGHT.
Not out here.
What about the 100?
There are communal facilities in the block halfway down the field.
FX: HE LIGHTS ANOTHER LAMP DURING THIS.
What? (MUTTERS) I knew it. Middle bloomin’ ages!
That’s also where you’1ll find the fresh water tap. There’s a pay-telephone by the main gate. If you need me, my caravan’s the one beside it.
That’s very helpful of you. Mister - ?
Percy Till. I’m the site manager. There is one more thing.
Yeah?
A little rule. The use of radios, cassette recorders and portable televisions is strictly forbidden.
What? Why?
It disturbs the other guests. (BEAT) You haven’t brought any such devices with you?
No, no, of course not.
Good. Well, that will be everything. You know where to find me.
FX: HE LEAVES, CLOSING THE DOOR BEHIND HIM.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 8
What was that all about?! “Disturbs the other guests”! There aren’t any other guests!
We don’t know that.
Oh come on, who else would be mad enough to want to come here?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 9
3. EXT. CARAVAN SITE. [CONTINUOUS]
FX: TARDIS MATERIALIZES IN THE RAIN. DOOR OPENS.
Okay, newsflash. This isn’t my wedding.
And this isn’t 1944. Doctor. You said you were taking me home.
Yes, I’m sorry about that, I’ll get you there eventually. But something came up.
FX: DOCTOR PUTS UP UMBRELLA.
Here we go. Brace yourself for a load of space jargon, Connie.
SMALL LAUGH
FX: DOCTOR LOCKS TARDIS DOOR.
Well, just for that. I was going to offer you both the shelter of my umbrella, but now I’m not so sure —
Come on, budge up, I’m getting soaked out here.
(BUDGES UP) Alright. The reason we’re here, ladies, is because the TARDIS detected some temporal interference.
“Temporal interference”?
A disturbance in the fabric of the space-time continuum.
And I would be right to infer that’s a bad thing?
FX: RAIN EASING OFF FROM NOW ON.
You would be very right indeed. Prolonged exposure can have all
sorts of... nasty side-effects.
And it’s here? In this caravan site?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 10
Hereabouts. The temporal disturbance is diffuse. It’s somewhere in this general area. Shouldn’t be too hard to find!
Well that’s not vague.
Doctor. We have company.
What? (SEES PERCY) Oh?
(APPROACHING) It’s the Doctor, isn’t it? Doctor! After all this time. How
good to see you again!
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 11
4. EXT. CARAVAN SITE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: DOOR OPENS, ANDY GOES DOWN THE STEPS OF HIS CARAVAN.
You were wrong, we’re not the only ones here.
No car, though. And that blue box. Was that there before? I don’t remember seeing it on the way in —
Keep an eye out, will you?
FX: ANDY OPENS CAR BOOT. NO RAIN FROM NOW ON.
An eye out for what?
FX: LIFTS ITEM OUT OF BOOT.
Wouldn’t want old Percy clocking this, would we?
You brought the portable?!
Well, you don’t expect me to miss the match, do you? (FX: HE
BOOT SHUT AND PICKS UP TELLY) And now you don’t have to miss Emmerdale Farm. Out the way.
FX: HE CLIMBS UP STEPS INTO CARAVAN.
Haven’t you forgotten something? No electricity.
No problem. We can run it off the car batteries. Even brought the wires, just in case. (HE PUTS DOWN TELLY) Look, while I’m setting this up, get the suitcases, could you, “Mrs Clover”?
FX: HE GOES INSIDE.
(JUMPS OVER PUDDLE, YUK!) Mrs Clover? In your dreams!
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 12
5. EXT. CARAVAN SITE [CONTINUOUS]
I’1ll put you in caravan two.
We’ve pre-booked, have we?
In a manner of speaking. The Doctor was expected.
I was? Expected by whom?
By me, sir. I - (HE’S DISCONCERTED BY CONSTANCE)
I’m sorry, would you mind not looking at me like that?
My apologies. Sometimes I.. forget myself.
I’m afraid you have me at a disadvantage... (FX: TAKES DOWN UMBRELLA) You wouldn’t care to remind me of your name?
Till. Percy Till. You don’t remember me?
I meet an awful lot of people, it’s no reflection on you. But you remember me, Percy...
Well, I’m hardly gonna forget you, am I, Doctor?
No, I suppose I am what you would call memorable!
And you haven’t changed a bit, while I.. well, I’m an old man now, no wonder you wouldn’t recognise me.
Interesting. But you don’t know my, ah, travelling companions — Philippa Jackson, and Constance Clarke?
No, I have not had the pleasure. Why, should I?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 13
No, just.. narrowing things down.
If you’1l follow me, I’11 show you to your caravan.
That’s very kind of you, Percy. Lead on!
FX: THEY WALK ON.
(TO FLIP, NOT WHISPERING BUT CLOSE) “Narrowing things down”?
The Doctor’s trying to work out whether the old guy is someone he hasn’t met yet, or someone he has met and forgotten.
Because if I haven’t met him yet, then I have to avoid asking too many questions about events in my own future.
(FROM UP AHEAD) It’s a good thing you arrived when you did. It’1ll be getting dark soon, and night falls quickly in these parts...
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 14
6. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN. [CONTINUOUS]
FX: ANDY IS FIDDLING WITH TELLY, TRYING TO TUNE IT IN. JUST
INTERFERENCE AND HISSING STATIC.
He’s taking them into the caravan opposite.
You’re turning into a right little curtain-twitcher.
Nothing else to do until you get that thing working.
It is working, it’s just.. (FX: BANGS IT) Stupid thing.
Well, that’s not gonna help.
There’s no reception. Same as the car radio.
After all that!
Hills must be in the way...
FX: HE KEEPS TRYING, LOUD BURST OF INTERFERENCE.
Turn it down!
FX: ANDY SWITCHES TELLY OFF.
Alright, keep your hair on.
Makes you wonder what the point of Percy’s ‘little rule’ is, if you can’t even pick up anything.
Fine. So what do we do now?
I thought the whole point of this trip was for us to spend some time together. To “work things out”. So. Let’s talk.
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 15
7. INT. DOCTOR’S CARAVAN
FX: IT’S CRAMPED IN THIS CARAVAN TOO. THEY CLAMBER IN.
Woah, it’s even smaller on the inside.
There’s a bedroom at the end, that’s for Philippa and I?
I assume that is the arrangement. There’s also a drop-down bed in the front for the Doctor.
FX: DOCTOR CHECKS CUPBOARDS.
Excellent. Well, this is quite the home from home. All mod- cons!
Where’s the telly?
I’m afraid that the use of radios, cassette recorders and portable televisions is strictly forbidden.
What?
- and quite right too! We didn’t come all this way to sit in front of the goggle-box, did we, Flip?
(CHEEKY) I don’t know, depends what’s on.
No, we came to see the sights. Percy, are there any local points of interest you would particularly recommend?
There’s a leaflet on the table. Well, I’1ll leave you to get settled in. If you need me, I’m in the caravan by the gate.
FX: HE GOES, CLOSING DOOR BEHIND HIM. DOCTOR UNFOLDS LEAFLET.
Now, this is interesting. There’s a stone circle not half a mile from here. According to this, the ancient Britons used it for human sacrifice.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 16
Something to do with the ‘time fissure’?
Very possibly. They may well have attributed temporal anomalies to some sort of deity. And there are the remains of a ruined monastery not far away too...
(SARCASTIC) Wow. It’s like Disneyland.
Apparently that’s how this area got its name. Abbey Marston.
Abbey Marston? Did you say Abbey Marston?
You’ve heard of it?
I’m not sure. I would need to look at a map.
There’s a drawing on the back, but it’s not much help —
No, I mean a detailed Ordnance Survey map, of the whole area.
We could ask around the other caravans. (FX: GETS UP) Well, anything beats sitting around here!
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 17
8. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
She got out of her depth. By the time I got to her, she'd already gone under three times. No-one could’ve saved her.
Andy. I don’t want to talk about this.
That’s just it. We never talk about it. And ever since, we've been like... this place! Stuck, not going anywhere! You won’t even let me touch you. It’s like you’re punishing me.
I’m not punishing you. The doctor said it would take time, to come to terms with it.
It’s been a year. A year of you hating me.
I don’t hate you, I don’t blame you. It’s not about you.
Then what is it about?

It’s about me. Cos I was too busy reading a stupid book to notice until it was too late. If I’d looked up just ten seconds earlier, maybe she would still be alive. She was drowning fifty yards away from me and I didn’t even hear her calling for help. My own sister, and I didn’t hear her.
Jo. I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean that. I just thought it might help to talk about her. (FX: HE UNZIPS A BAG) To actually take some time, to remember her.
What?
Rather than burying it all away. So, anyway, I brought some photos. Of Susannah.
FX: HE OPENS JESSOP’S ENVELOPE, SPREADS PHOTOS OVER TABLE.
I can’t believe this.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 18
So we can remember what she was like when she was alive.
Hang on, some of these are from the holiday. From the day she
died...
I know, I had the film in my camera for ages.
Put them away.
What?
I don’t want to look at them, put them away!
Alright, alright. (FX: SCOOPS UP PHOTOS INTO ENVELOPE)
Why are you doing this? Why are you doing this to me?
I just thought —
You just thought? You didn’t think, that’s your trouble. If you did, you’d know, they’re the last thing I want to see...
I’m sorry.
FX: JOANNA GETS UP.
I’m going outside.
But where —
FX: JOANNA OPENS DOOR.
I don’t know. I just need to be somewhere you’re not!
FX: SHE LEAVES.
Suit yourself. Can’t do right for doing wrong around here.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 19
FX: HE SWITCHES ON TELLY. LOW LEVEL OF STATIC INTERFERENCE.
Now, let’s see if I can get this thing to work...
FX: HE ADJUSTS TELLY. MORE SHARP, HISSING STATIC.
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL)
9. INT. CAR/CARAVAN SITE.
ANGRY SOBBING
FX: TAPS ON A WINDOW.
STARTLED
Hello? Hello?
FX: WINDOW WOUND DOWN.
Yeah, what?
Sorry to disturb you and all that, we just need
You’ve just arrived, haven’t you? You’re in the
That’s right, yeah. I’m Philippa, Flip, this is guy with all the colours likes to be called the
“All the colours”?
Page 20
a bit of help.
other caravan.
Connie, and the Doctor.
Thing is, we got a bit lost on our way here, walking through
the wood, and was wondering if you had a map?
A map?
Just so we know where we are?
Hang on. (FX: GLOVE COMPARTMENT OPENS, MAP OUT) Here you go.
Cheers, won’t be a tic.
FX: CAR DOOR OPENS. WE MOVE OUTSIDE. WIND IN TREES.
(GETTING OUT) No, don’t worry about it, you can keep it!
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 21
FX: SHE SLAMS DOOR AND STOMPS OFF.
(CALLS AFTER HER) Hey, wait, are you alright? (TO DOCTOR) Leave this with me.
FX: SHE THRUSTS MAP INTO DOCTOR’S HANDS AND RUNS AFTER HER.
(RUNNING OFF) Hey! Wait! (NEARLY FALLS OVER) Wait!
That girl has to be the most impetuous, irresponsible -
She sees someone upset, she can’t help getting involved. Just like someone else I could mention.
Point taken. So, Constance, what exactly are we looking for?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 22
10. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
FX: ANDY CONTINUES TO ADJUST TELLY. MORE SHARP, HISSING STATIC.
Come on, come on.. Where are you, I know you’re out there...
FX: THEN A VOICE, BARELY AUDIBLE AT FIRST, HEAVILY DISTORTED,
BUT SLOWLY GROWING CLEARER. AS SPOOKY AS POSSIBLE!
(FX: STATIC) Help me... help me, please... help me... help me, please... somebody help me...
(OVER THIS) (THIS IS WHAT HE WANTED) There you are. I knew it!
FX: THE INTERFERENCE SHARPLY GROWS LOUDER, OBSCURING THE VOICE.
VOLUME IN BOTH CHANNELS FOR HALF A SECOND.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 23
11. EXT. CAMPSITE.
FX: COIN-OPERATED PHONE. JOANNA PUTS COIN IN, DIALS.
Oh, what?
FX: SLAMS DOWN RECEIVER. RATTLES IT, TRIES AGAIN, SLAMS IT.
No luck?
No dial tone. Even if I had the number of a taxi firm, they probably wouldn’t come out here.
You’re trying to leave?
Since when was it any of your business?
Sorry, I’1ll go.
No, it’s not you. It’s... boyfriend trouble. Well, fiancée trouble, technically.
Oh, I’ve been there.
You’ve been where?
I mean, tell me about it. If you want.
FX: THEY WALK.
It was all his idea. Andy’s. That we should go away to ‘work things out’. My sister died last year, you see —
I’m sorry.
Thanks. Anyway, Andy thinks the best way of helping me ‘come terms’ with it is to sit around and talk about her. He even brought along a bunch of photos.
to
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 24
What an idiot.
Exactly. What an idiot, right?
But he was trying to help, though.
What?
I mean, in his own stupid way. You know, a lot of blokes would just walk away. Too difficult.
I suppose I haven’t been the easiest person to get along with.
And he’s put up with you.
(SMILES) Not half as much as I’ve put up with him.
FX: PERCY APPROACHING.
Well, that’s always how it works. (SEES PERCY) Woah, someone’s not happy.
Did you just make a phone call?
I’m sorry, what?
Did you just make a phone call?
Well, no, cos the line’s dead, isn’t it? Some campsite you’re running here. Even the phone doesn’t work!
The phone works. We’ve been cut off.
Eh?
The stupid idiot... he doesn’t know what he’s doing...
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 25
FX: HE GOES OFF, FUMING.
Some people!
Yeah, touchy, much! (SHIVERS) Shall we get back, only I’m freezing my bits off out here.
Yeah, it — (SEES SOMETHING) Woah, where did that come from?
What?
The mist, look at it.. it’s like a wall of fog...
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 26
12. INT. DOCTOR’S CARAVAN.
FX: MAP UNROLLED ONTO TABLE. LAMP MOVED BESIDE IT.
So, let’s see. The circle’s here, the monastery’s here, and the village of Abbey Marston... but the rest is just fields and woods.
Not quite. (FX: FINGER ON MAP) There! I was right. I knew I'd heard the name before!
I’m not entirely sure what I’m supposed to be looking at.
A road that leads to nowhere? This whole area has been deliberately left blank.
Something has been kept off the map?
Yes. Abbey Marston Manor.
A house?
An R.A.F. research station.
Researching what?
Some sort of top-secret project. So top-secret nobody was supposed to know the place even existed. I only found out by accident.
And it’s still being kept secret, forty years later...
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 27
13. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
FX: TV ON, STATIC, QUIET. OUTSIDE, MUFFLED:
You’re sure you'll be alright?
Yeah. Thanks. I’ll see you around.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Andy? Andy?
In here.
FX: JOANNA ENTERS, CLOSES DOOR.
You alright?
Not really, no. It’s brass monkeys out there.
Sit over here, soon warm you up.
FX: SHE DOES.
You’re not still trying to get a picture on that thing, you?
No. But I have managed to get something.
What?
A.. Signal. But I don’t want you to freak out or panic.
What, like CB? Or police radio?
Something like that. But you have to promise me, you’re gonna run off again.
are
not
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 28
I’m not promising anything, just show me whatever it is.
Okay.
FX: ANDY TURNS UP VOLUME OF TV SET. STATIC LOUDER.
What? A grey fuzz?
Just listen.
FX: MORE STATIC.
(LAUGHS) What am I supposed to hear?
Shhh. Listen.
What? It’s just static —
FX: AS SHE SAYS STATIC, WE HEAR THE VOICE AS BEFORE, VERY QUIET
AT FIRST, GROWING CLEARER, LOUDER.
(FX: STATIC) Help me... help me, please... help me... somebody help me... (CONTINUES IN BACKGROUND, REPEATING ETC)
(OVER THIS) This isn’t funny. Why are you doing this?
I’m not doing anything.
You've set up a tape recorder, this is all some sick joke for you,, isn’t: 1?
No. It’s not me. It’s her. It’s really her. It’s Susannah.
Help me... Please... (CRIES OUT WITH A SCREAM) Joanna!
No. Stop its. Turn it. off! Turn it off! Turn 1t -off!
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
14. EXT. CARAVAN SITE.
FX: DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE WALKING.
This fog.. I’ve never seen anything like it, not even in London before the war.
Yes. It does rather seem to have come out of nowhere.
What do you mean? It’s not natural?
I’m not sure it’s even - Ah! Flip! There you are!
FX: FLIP RUNS OVER TO THEM.
(STOPS RUNNING) Were you looking for me?
Actually, we were on our way to return the map -
(FROM INSIDE CARAVAN)
SCREAM
What was that?
That was Joanna.
Flip, Constance. Go back to our caravan.
What? No.
Please, for once, do as I say!
What — but —
Don’t argue. Go!
FX: HE RUNS OFF.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
15. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
FX: TV IS NOW OFF.
SOBBING
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Hey, what do you want?
I heard a scream.
Oh, did you? So what?
It’s Joanna, isn’t it? What happened?
It’s him. He was playing some trick.
Trick?
He set up the telly to make my sister’s voice come out of it.
Your sister?
She died, about a year ago.
And her voice came through the television set?
Yeah, I was just trying to get a signal, and I could hear her, calling out. Not that it’s anything to do with you.
FX: DOCTOR EXAMINES TELEVISION.
Well, it doesn’t appear to have been tampered with.
It’s not a trick. Why would I do something like that?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
But if it’s not... which channel were you tuned to?
I don’t know. I wasn’t tuned to any channel. It was just static, interference.
Oh. Television static isn’t just static.
No?
No. It is the sound of the birth of the universe.
What?
Cosmic noise. The afterglow of the Big Bang. And if what you
heard really was your sister, calling from beyond the grave...
A ghost? What we heard was a ghost?
Well, there’s only one way to find out.
FX: HE TURNS TELEVISION ON. STATIC ONCE MORE.
Jo, do you want to go in the other room?
No, I’m staying. If it’s her.. I’m staying.
Shhh.
FX: JUST STATIC. THEN DOOR IS FORCED OPEN.
JOANNA/ANDY : (SHRIEK OF ALARM)/Hey, what’s going on?
Percy, please — just put the axe down —
FX: PERCY KNOCKS TELEVISION OFF TABLE. THE WIRE SPUTTERS AS
IS DISCONNECTED.
IT
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 32
Hey!!
I told you. No radios, no cassette players, no televisions. (FX: HE SMASHES TELEVISION.) Now leave. Before it’s too late.
FX: HE STOMPS OUT, HALF-CLOSING DOOR BEHIND HIM.
Bleedin’ heck, the guy’s an a-grade nutter.
I’m not sure.
He just smashed up my telly! He’s a maniac!
You heard him, we should leave.
FX: GETS UP, OPENS DOOR.
Jo-
I’m not staying here a minute longer. I want to go home!
FX: SHE GOES OUT.
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 33
16. EXT. WOODS.
FX: FLIP AND CONSTANCE WALKING THROUGH BRAMBLES AND BUSHES.
RUSTLING AND CREAKING IN THE WIND.
This isn’t the way back to the caravan.
Hey, don’t blame me, blame the fog!
(PICKING BRAMBLES OFF HER SHOE) Marvellous. We must’ve wandered into the woods.
It’s not a problem. We just keep going, eventually we’1ll get somewhere. At least we can still see.
Yes. That’s odd. It’s still... twilight.
What?
It should’ve got dark by now, but it hasn’t. It’s just mist in every direction. Like it’s closing in on us...
FX: THEY TRUDGE ON.
Well, we just have to keep going until we’re out the other side.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 34
17. EXT. CARAVAN SITE.

JOANNA: You've set up a tape recorder, this is all some sick joke for you,, isn’t: 1?
ANDY: No. It’s not me. It’s her. It’s really her. It’s Susannah.
SUSANNAH: Help me... Please... (CRIES OUT WITH A SCREAM) Joanna!
JOANNA: No. Stop its. Turn it. off! Turn it off! Turn 1t -off!
JOANNA: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
CONSTANCE: This fog.. I’ve never seen anything like it, not even in London before the war.
DOCTOR: Yes. It does rather seem to have come out of nowhere.
CONSTANCE: What do you mean? It’s not natural?
DOCTOR: I’m not sure it’s even - Ah! Flip! There you are!
FLIP: (STOPS RUNNING) Were you looking for me?
CONSTANCE: Actually, we were on our way to return the map -
JOANNA: (FROM INSIDE CARAVAN)
CONSTANCE: What was that?
FLIP: That was Joanna.
DOCTOR: Flip, Constance. Go back to our caravan.
FLIP: What? No.
DOCTOR: Please, for once, do as I say!
CONSTANCE: What — but —
DOCTOR: Don’t argue. Go!
DOCTOR: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
ANDY: Hey, what do you want?
DOCTOR: I heard a scream.
ANDY: Oh, did you? So what?
DOCTOR: It’s Joanna, isn’t it? What happened?
JOANNA: It’s him. He was playing some trick.
DOCTOR: Trick?
JOANNA: He set up the telly to make my sister’s voice come out of it.
DOCTOR: Your sister?
JOANNA: She died, about a year ago.
DOCTOR: And her voice came through the television set?
ANDY: Yeah, I was just trying to get a signal, and I could hear her, calling out. Not that it’s anything to do with you.
DOCTOR: Well, it doesn’t appear to have been tampered with.
ANDY: It’s not a trick. Why would I do something like that?
ANDY: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR: But if it’s not... which channel were you tuned to?
ANDY: I don’t know. I wasn’t tuned to any channel. It was just static, interference.
DOCTOR: Oh. Television static isn’t just static.
JOANNA: No?
DOCTOR: No. It is the sound of the birth of the universe.
ANDY: What?
DOCTOR: Cosmic noise. The afterglow of the Big Bang. And if what you
DOCTOR: heard really was your sister, calling from beyond the grave...
JOANNA: A ghost? What we heard was a ghost?
DOCTOR: Well, there’s only one way to find out.
ANDY: Jo, do you want to go in the other room?
JOANNA: No, I’m staying. If it’s her.. I’m staying.
DOCTOR: Shhh.
DOCTOR: JOANNA/ANDY : (SHRIEK OF ALARM)/Hey, what’s going on?
DOCTOR: Percy, please — just put the axe down —
DOCTOR: IS DISCONNECTED.
DOCTOR: IT
DOCTOR: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 32
ANDY: Hey!!
PERCY: I told you. No radios, no cassette players, no televisions. (FX: HE SMASHES TELEVISION.) Now leave. Before it’s too late.
ANDY: Bleedin’ heck, the guy’s an a-grade nutter.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure.
ANDY: He just smashed up my telly! He’s a maniac!
JOANNA: You heard him, we should leave.
ANDY: Jo-
JOANNA: I’m not staying here a minute longer. I want to go home!
JOANNA: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 33
TREES: RUSTLING AND CREAKING IN THE WIND.
CONSTANCE: This isn’t the way back to the caravan.
FLIP: Hey, don’t blame me, blame the fog!
CONSTANCE: (PICKING BRAMBLES OFF HER SHOE) Marvellous. We must’ve wandered into the woods.
FLIP: It’s not a problem. We just keep going, eventually we’1ll get somewhere. At least we can still see.
CONSTANCE: Yes. That’s odd. It’s still... twilight.
FLIP: What?
CONSTANCE: It should’ve got dark by now, but it hasn’t. It’s just mist in every direction. Like it’s closing in on us...
FLIP: Well, we just have to keep going until we’re out the other side.
FLIP: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 34
ANDY: It’s gonna be a hell of a job, driving back through this...
JOANNA: Better than staying here and getting killed.
DOCTOR: I don’t think Percy intends you any harm.
ANDY: I’m not planning on sticking around to find out.
DOCTOR: But you did break his little rule.
ANDY: So he bursts in with an axe?
DOCTOR: I don’t think you’re in any danger from him. But you’re right about one thing. It’s certainly not safe to stay.
ANDY: What about you, do you and your birds want a lift?
DOCTOR: My associates and I will not be needing a lift, no. But I should be getting back to them. (FX: PATS CAR ROOF) Drive carefully!
JOANNA: What do you think he meant, it’s not safe?
ANDY: (FX: DOING UP SEATBELT) Who cares? We’re leaving.
TURNING: OVER.
TURNING: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 35
ANDY: Damn, come on —
JOANNA: Was is it?
ANDY: Battery’s flat.
JOANNA: What? (REALISES) The telly! You must’ve used up all the power.
ANDY: What? In half an hour? (FX: HE THUMPS STEERING WHEEL)
JOANNA: Can’t you jump start it?
ANDY: From what? No other cars. (FX: UNDOES SEATBELT) Nothing else for it. We’ll have to get out and push...
JOANNA: Both of us?
ANDY: Unless you want to be stuck here for the rest of your life!
ANDY: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 36
ANDY: ON, GROWING LOUDER FROM SILENCE.
CONSTANCE: Flip, what is it?
FLIP: I can’t go on. Not this way.
CONSTANCE: What?
FLIP: We have to go back. Can’t you feel it?
CONSTANCE: Feel what?
FLIP: I don’t know... it’s like.. there’s something out there.
CONSTANCE: Somewhere ahead of us?
FLIP: Yes. You feel it too?
CONSTANCE: Now you mention it. There is something. A sense of dread.
FLIP: Yeah. And a sound...
FLIP: VOICES IN IT, SOFTLY TALKING.
CONSTANCE: You’re right. We should turn back. With me!
CONSTANCE: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 37
PERCY: (DESPONDENT, BLAMING HIMSELF) Yes?
DOCTOR: Hello again.
PERCY: I’m sorry, Doctor. I’ve let you down.
DOCTOR: What?
PERCY: The television — I didn’t know he’d brought it in -
DOCTOR: Why did you destroy it?
PERCY: Because I had to, didn’t I?
DOCTOR: Why? What did you think would happen?
PERCY: The idiots. The stupid, stupid idiots!
CROSS TO: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 38
JOANNA: AS SHE APPROACHES THE PHONE/US.
ANDY: Jo! What are you doing?
JOANNA: Half an hour ago that phone wasn’t working.
ANDY: So, it’s been repaired.
JOANNA: Then whoever it is can call back later and I can call us a taxi.
PERCY: (APPROACHING) Don’t answer that phone.
JOANNA: (THINKS HE JOKING) Why? Is it for you?
PERCY: Don’t answer it! Leave it alone!
DOCTOR: (APPROACHING) I think you should do as the man asks -
JOANNA: Hello?
SUSANNAH: (FX: OTHER END OF THE PHONE) I’m coming.
ANDY: Who was it?
JOANNA: (CAN BARELY BELIEVE IT) Susannah. It was Susannah.
PERCY: I warned you. But you wouldn’t listen.
PERCY: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 39
DOCTOR: What’s going on here? Percy? Tell me!
DOCTOR: FLIP/CONSTANCE: (CALLING) Doctor!/There you are!
DOCTOR: Flip — Constance — what’s happened to you!
CONSTANCE: We went for a walk in the woods.
DOCTOR: What?
FLIP: But that’s not the half of it. We had to turn back, cos there was this feeling —
PERCY: None of us can leave now. You, Philippa. What time is it?
FLIP: What?
PERCY: You have a watch, don’t you? What time is it?
FLIP: Nineteen minutes past six. No, hang on. (CHECKS IT) Hey. It’s not ticking. It’s stopped.
CONSTANCE: (CHECKS HER WATCH) So has mine!
PERCY: No. It’s not your watches that have stopped.
DOCTOR: It’s time. We’re caught in a single instant of time.
CONSTANCE: (SEES SOMETHING) Look.
CONSTANCE: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 40
FLIP: There’s somebody in the mist.
DOCTOR: A. girl.
CONSTANCE: In a bathing costume — she’s soaking wet?!
SUSANNAH: Help me. Please. I’m drowning.
JOANNA: No. No! It’s her. It’s my sister. Susannah.
DOCTOR: (QUIETLY TO HIMSELF) The ghost made flesh.
SUSANNAH: Help me. Please. Joanna! You have to help me. Please...
CRASH: INTO CLOSING THEME!
CRASH: END OF PART ONE
CRASH: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL)

elements.text: PART TWO
MUSIC: OPENING THEME.
(SEES SOMETHING) Look.
SURPRISED GASP
There’s somebody in the mist.
A girl:,
Page 41
In a bathing costume — she’s soaking wet?!
FX: AS SUSANNAH GETS NEARER, WE HEAR HER:
Help me. Please. I’m drowning.
No. No! It’s her. It’s my sister. Susannah.
The ghost made flesh.
Help me. Please. Joanna! You have to help me. Please...
21. EXT. CARAVAN SITE [CONTINUOUS]
Stay back, everyone. Stay back!
But she’s my sister.
Let’s not leap to any assumptions.
Why, why should I?
Let me deal with this.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 42
Cos he’s a doctor.
FX: DOCTOR APPROACHES HER.
Hello. Susannah, isn’t it?
Who are you? Where am I? I — (LOSES CONSCIOUSNESS )
FX: DOCTOR CATCHES HER.
(CATCHING HER) Well, she’s solid enough. Alright, let’s get her inside.
Our caravan’s closest.
Then perhaps you could help me, Andy?
Alright. (HELPS SUPPORT HER)
What about me, what should I do?
Clear a bed, find some clothes for her... and prepare a warm drink. Flip and Constance will help.
JOANNA/FLIP: Right, yes./Yep. (FX: THEY GO.)
(CARRYING SUSANNAH) Well, Andy. It seems you’ve succeeded in bringing your girlfriend’s sister back from the dead.
(HELPING CARRY HER) What?
I assume it was intentional. Hence the television set. You were hoping this would happen, weren’t you?
I don’t know what you’re talking about, Doctor. You’re the expert.
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page
24. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
FX: JOANNA’S MAKING HOT CHOCOLATE ON A STOVE.
Look, Andy, there’s not room in here for you as well.
What?
Just go for a walk, sit in the car, I don’t care.
FX: DOOR CLOSES.
(WAKING UP) What... Joanna? Joanna.
It’s okay, stay in bed. You need to keep warm.
(SEES DOCTOR) Who are you?
I’m the Doctor.
Is there something wrong with me? (PANICS) Where am I?
It’s alright, you’re safe.
I’ve made you some hot chocolate. Your favourite, right?
FX: SHE HANDS IT OVER.
Yeah. I.. (DRINKS) What’s going on? This isn’t the hotel.
No, it’s a caravan in the middle of nowhere.
What?
Tell me, Susannah. What’s the last thing you remember?
Sorry?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 44
You woke up this morning, what did you do next?

(NOT SURE WHERE THIS IS LEADING) Well, I had breakfast in the hotel, with Jo and Andy. Then we went for a wander around the old town, did some postcards, then went down to the beach. Jo had her head stuck in her Danielle Steel, so I went for a swim...
And after that?
(TRYING TO PIN DOWN MEMORY) I remember, I got tired... and when I tried to touch the bottom, I couldn’t reach and went under...
Oh no.
Then I came up, and I was calling for help, screaming, but nobody could hear me. I could see you, Jo - you were still reading your book, but you didn’t look up.
I’m sorry, I’m so sorry.
Sorry? What are you sorry for?
Cause you died, Susannah. You died.
(THINKS JOANNA’S JOKING) What?
Andy dragged you onto the beach, gave you the kiss of life and everything, but it was too late.
But I’m alright, aren’t I? I’m not dead.
No, you seem very much alive. But you remember nothing after that?
No, but... why, why should I?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 45
Because that was a year ago.
What?
That’s how long you’ve been away.
Away? Where? Where I’ve been?
That is the question. If you’1ll excuse me...
FX: HE GETS UP.
But I haven’t been anywhere!
FX: DOCTOR OPENS DOOR, GOES OUT, CLOSES IT.
We had your body flown home, we had a funeral, you were buried. Oh, Susannah. I’ve missed you so much! I’ve missed you so much!
FX: SHE HUGS HER.
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 46
27. EXT. CARAVAN PARK.
FX: DOCTOR, FLIP AND CONSTANCE WALKING.
It can’t really be her, can it?
Can’t it? Why not?
I mean, this must be a, I don’t know, a robot or something.
No. She’s flesh and blood.
Or a clone, then!
I suppose that is better than the alternative.
Which is? (BEAT) That she’s the real Susannah.
Quite. She remembers everything up to the moment of her death.
But nothing after that?
“For in that sleep of death what dreams may come,
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause.” (BEAT) But that’s not what concerns me.
It isn’t?
What did she look like, when she walked out of the mist?
She was wearing a bathing costume, I don’t see —
Exactly. She looked like she had been plucked out of time at the precise instant of her death.
The temporal interference?!
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 47
Quite. But if her death has now been averted...
That’s changing history.
FX: THEY HALT.
I think our friend Mr Till knows more than he’s letting on.
You’re not going to see that man again?
You disapprove?
I don’t trust him. The way he looked at me when we first met... it was like I had no right to exist.
Yes. Then I suggest you wait inside. Keep warm. (FX: TAPS SIDE OF CARAVAN) I won’t be long!
FX: HE HEADS OFF.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 48
28. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN
SLEEPING THROUGH SCENE — BREATHING BUT NOT SNORING
FX: DOOR OPENS.
(ENTERING) Can I come in? How is she?
Sleeping. (BEAT) What did you do, Andy?
What?
It was your idea to come here. Your idea to bring a telly, and the photos. You did... this. You made this happen.
I couldn’t tell you, I didn’t know for sure it would work.
If what would work?
You have to be remembering them as they were when they died, for them to come back. That’s what they say.
They? Who’s they?
That’s not important. All that matters is that she’s alive now.
I saved her. For you. I did it all for you.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 49
29. INT. PERCY’S CARAVAN.
He brought her back from the brink of death. But how?
I can’t tell you, Doctor.
But you know, don’t you? Because you were trying to stop it happening.
FX: PERCY MOVES AROUND THE CARAVAN, MAKING TEA.
I’ve done nothing else for the past forty years.
Forty years?
Others have tried, of course. They hear stories about this place, rumours, and come to try and bring back their loved ones. But I’ve always stopped them, before.
By smashing their radios and television sets?
Because that’s part of it, don’t you see?
Because the act of remembering creates a psychic link between the past and the present. The voice that Joanna heard was the link being established...
You know more about it than I do. All I know is that’s there’s something about this place that means the dead don’t stay dead.
When you say this place, you mean this caravan site?
No, we're on the very edge of it here. It’s like a circle.
Show me on the map.
FX: HE UNFOLDS IT, LAYS IT OUT ON THE TABLE.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 50
We’re here. The stone circle’s at the centre, and it’s about half a mile all around.
So the affected area includes the abandoned monastery?

That’s why the monks left. It wasn’t the reformation that did for them. It was all their dead buddies turning up after they’d buried them. As soon as they remembered them in their prayers, down came the mist... bringing the dead with it.
So, within this perimeter, time is at a standstill. There’s no past or future, only the here and now. The question is, how do we get time moving again?
Ah, well, I can’t tell you that.
Can’t? Because you don’t know or because you don’t want to tell me?
Because I’m not allowed to. You’1ll just have to work it out for yourself, won’t you?
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 51
30. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
STILL SLEEPING
I still can’t believe she’s alive. Oh my god, mum and dad! They’re gonna be over the moon when they find out.
Listen. We’re gonna have to be careful. If this gets out, the press will go bananas.
So? We can sell our story, make some money.
Don’t be stupid. They’1ll say it was a miracle. There’1l be people flocking here to bring back their dead relatives.
And what’s so bad about that?
That can’t happen.
What, cos you want it to stay as your little secret?
No. We just have to keep this quiet. (FX: ANDY GETS UP, MOVES
CARAVAN) We’re gonna have to wake her.
No. Let her sleep.
We have to get away from here as soon as possible.
How? We tried. The car won’t start.
We can push it. Or walk to the village, if we have to. But we have to go. Now!
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 52
31. INT. DOCTOR’S CARAVAN.
So you know about this place, what’s it called? Abbey Marston?
Just that there was an R.A.F. station here during the war. I don’t even know if it’s still here.
Maybe we should go and check?
And get ourselves lost again? And besides, the Doctor said we should wait here.
And you always do what the Doctor tells you?
I respect his advice. As should you. (BEAT) Though I wish he wouldn’t keep finding excuses for not taking us home.
You’ve had enough?
It just feels like my whole life is on hold. I’d quite like to resume it. And besides, you have a wedding to go to!
Yeah, don’t remind me. I’m sure the Doctor will get us where we need to be. Eventually. Maybe he finds it hard, saying goodbye.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Ah, speak of the devil.
Ladies, you’re probably bored rigid sitting around waiting for
me. How do you fancy a little field trip?
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 53
32. EXT. CARAVAN SITE.
FX: ANDY CARRIES SUSANNAH DOWN STEPS.
(HALF AWAKE) Wha-?
Shush, it’s alright. Jo, open the back, could you?
Shouldn’t it have got dark by now?
Never mind that, just open her up.
FX: JOANNA OPENS CAR DOOR.
(PUTS SUSANNAH INSIDE) Right. Now get ready to push.
It won’t work, you know.
(STARTLED, WHERE THE HELL DID HE SPRING FROM?) What?
You can’t leave. Not while you have her with you.
Oh really. And who’s gonna stop us? You?
No, not me. The mist.
What?
But you don’t have to take my word for it. Please, go ahead and try. See how far you get! (LAUGHS)
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 54
33. EXT. STONE CIRCLE.
FX: DOCTOR AND FRIENDS WALKING THROUGH BRAMBLES.
There’s no mist this way?
No. I think it only acts as a barrier around the perimeter.
That sense of dread I felt, that was to stop me leaving?
Yes. Literally a psychological barrier. Whereas now we are Slap-bang in the centre.
FX: THEY EMERGE INTO AN EXPOSED AREA.
The stone circle?
I think it’s safe to assume it was constructed because of the... properties of the area.
People returning from the dead.
Perhaps it was used to gather people together in remembrance, to summon those they had lost.
So, this place, it can bring back anyone who has died, just by you thinking about them?
As long as the feeling is strong enough.
So that’s why Andy brought all those photos of Susannah.
To intensify Joanna’s sense of loss, yes.
What a git!
But this stone circle isn’t causing this “effect”?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 55
No. The source must be underground and ancient. Buried in the Earth since before the dawn of mankind...
Buried? By who?
Impossible to tell. A relic of a long-forgotten war? Or a gift to help foster humanity? Either way, these stones are probably just a marker.
And they are? Just stones?
FX: DOCTOR PATS ONE.
(GENTLY MOCKING HER) As far as one can tell.
But you said it was used for human sacrifice.
Ah. That was the leaflet, not me.
I think the idea of the Celts practising human sacrifice was just a myth put about the Romans, to justify wiping them out.
(SHE SITS) So what were these two big rocks used for?
Ah. They probably did practice animal sacrifice.
Ugh. You mean these are basically two big butcher’s slabs?
Well, sacrificial altars. For goats, chicken, wild boar. It’s odd that there are two of them, though.
Yes. You’d think that one would be enough...
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 56
34. INT. JOANNA’S CARAVAN.
(OUTSIDE DOOR) Jo! It’s me.
FX: HE OPENS DOOR.
Well? Can we leave?
FX: ANDY CLOSES DOOR BEHIND HIM.
(ENTERING)

No. It’s no good. I tried, but it was like the old man said. As soon as I walked into the mist, there was this feeling pushing me back. It’s hard to describe. It was like every step was bringing me closer to death. It was like... I could hear them, whispering to me. The dead!
So we’re stuck here.
(WAKING) What — what did you say?
It doesn’t matter. Go back to sleep.
No, you said something. About us being stuck here.
That’s right. None of us can leave. Not while you’re here.
Andy, why didn’t you think about this before?
Because I didn’t know!
Oh, I’m sorry. I thought you’d got it all worked out!
Stop it! Please! Both of you. (BEAT) Andy. You mean I can never leave here? I can never go back home and see mum and dad again?
That’s what it looks like, yes.
Can I talk to them, on the telephone?
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 57
I tried the phone again on the way back. It’s dead.
It doesn’t matter. The only thing that matters is that you’re here, you’re alive again.
But what’s the point if I can never go anywhere? Why did you have to bring me back? I was dead. Why did you have to bring me back?
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 58
35. EXT. MANOR RUINS.
FX: DOCTOR WALKING THROUGH OVERGROWN RUBBLE, RAFTERS SHIFTING
AND CREAKING IN THE BREEZE.
(CALLS OUT) Well, I think it’s safe to say this station is no longer active.
FX: CONSTANCE APPROACHES, PICKING HER WAY OVER RUBBLE.
That’s something of an understatement. There’s no roof, what’s left is falling to bits. It looks like a bomb hit it.
Maybe it did. Even the best-kept secrets can be discovered.
But it’s still being left off the maps. Which means they’re still trying to keep it quiet. Unless there is something here that poses a threat. Radiation? Or chemical waste?
Well, it can’t be that bad, or we wouldn’t still be breathing.
(SARCASTIC) That’s very reassuring.
Plus, look! Birds’ nests. Swallows. They’ve been coming back
here year after year, raising their young.
But they’re not here now. (BEAT) It’s so quiet.
Well, until Flip gets here. Where is she?
I thought she was with you.
No. I thought she was with you.
MUSIC LINK.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 59
36. EXT. CARAVAN PARK.
FX: FLIP APPROACHING.
Lost your friends?
Not quite. They were busy looking round some old ruin, I thought I’d leave them to it.
You’ve been to the manor? Didn’t you see the signs?
Yeah, but unfortunately when you or I see a sign saying ‘Danger Keep Out’, the Doctor sees a ‘Welcome’ mat. Why? Is there something there he shouldn’t see?
No. No, there’s nothing there now.
FX: THE CAMPSITE TELEPHONE RINGS. CONTINUES IN B/G.
Phone’s ringing.
I won’t be for me.
Why? Doesn’t anyone ever call you?
They used to, but I never answered, and then they stopped calling. No, if the phone’s ringing now, it’s for you. If you know what’s good for you, you won’t answer it.
Why not? (BEAT) Cos it’s someone else that’s dead, isn’t it? Like Susannah. It’ll bring them back. Someone I know that’s dead...
FX: PHONE HAS STOPPED RINGING DURING THIS. FLIP ANSWERS IT.
Hello? Hello? (NO REPLY) There’s no-one there. (FX: SHE RETURNS RECEIVER) So, Percy - (SEES HE’S WANDERING OFF) Hey, come back!
(FX: HE SHUTS DOOR OF CARAVAN) Oh, be like that!
FX: DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE ARE ABOUT TEN YARDS AWAY.
DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 60
(CALLS OUT) Philippa!
(APPROACHING) We thought you’d got lost in the mist.
(THINKING ON HER FEET) Yeah, and I ended up back here. You were right about there being no way out.
I’m afraid there’s a very good reason why we’re cut off from the outside world.
What’s that?
There’s something here that allows visitors to rescue the dead from the brink of death. So the only way to prevent a temporal paradox is if they are returned from whence they came.
To die. You mean, they have to die.
Yes. Only then will history remain unchanged. And until they are sent back, this place remains... outside time.
But we can still leave, in the TARDIS?
True. But that won’t do Joanna and Andy any good. Susannah has
to be returned to her own timeline, painful as that may be.
And once she goes back, things will return to normal?
I think so. The mist will rise, the power will come back on, and Andy and Joanna will be able to drive away.
FX: THEY HALT.
But we're leaving?

WRENS: Pilot Officer Ernest Brown returned to point of origin. Flight Lieutenant John Linder returned to point of origin. Pilot Officer James Whittle returned to point of origin. Flying Officer Ian Tate returned to point of origin. Navigator Reginald Hobbs returned to point of origin. Pilot Officer Harold Oakford return to point of origin.

DOCTOR: Nothing.
CONSTANCE: Nothing at all.

WEBSTER: Sir!

DOCTOR: I don’t think they did.
CONSTANCE: What?
CONSTANCE: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 92
DOCTOR: This skeleton isn’t the remains of a human. It’s partially- formed.
CONSTANCE: Partially-formed? You mean... grown?
DOCTOR: Yes. I think it gestated inside this trunk, with this (FX: GLOOP) as some sort of amniotic fluid.
CONSTANCE: Like an embryo? But it’s an adult!
DOCTOR: Yes. Which raises several disturbing possibilities.
CONSTANCE: There are more of them over here. (FX: SHE TRAMPS OVER TO THEM,
MOVING: AWAY FROM US) Five... six...
DOCTOR: All at the same stage of development?
CONSTANCE: No, no. This one has muscle tissue, internal organs, a brain. You were right. They’re being fabricated from the inside out.
DOCTOR: But the process has been interrupted. They’re no longer needed,
DOCTOR: so the material is being re-absorbed.
CONSTANCE: Not all of them. I think this one’s finished.
DOCTOR: And breathing. Help me!
DOCTOR: (PULLS) There.
CONSTANCE: Ugh, it’s covered in — (YUK!)
CONSTANCE: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 93
DOCTOR: It? Don’t you recognise him?
CONSTANCE: (RECOGNIZES HIM) Oh. Oh. I see what you mean.

DOCTOR: Why? Because then we might realise you’re not carrying a gun?
YOUNG PERCY: I said don’t move! (NOTICES BODY) What are you doing, anyway? What’s that?

YOUNG PERCY: Him?
DOCTOR: It’s you, Percy. Another you!
DOCTOR: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 94
JOANNA: Hang on. Your mate was in the second world war?
FLIP: Yeah, she did code breaking at Bletchley Park.
JOANNA: Where?
FLIP: Oh, it’s not famous yet. But if Percy met her, that means he was at the R.A.F. place too!
JOANNA: What R.A.F. place?
FLIP: Abbey Marston, the ruin on the other side of the woods. But what was he doing there? And how did he end up with her I.D.?

OLD PERCY: (NARRATION, OVERLAP WITH FLIP’S LINE)
OLD PERCY: . a search was in progress. But he told me he had a plan. Between us we lifted the sham and carried it through the woods to an ancient stone circle...
CROSS: INTO NEXT SCENE FROM NARRATION:
CROSS: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 95
YOUNG PERCY: What are we doing here?
DOCTOR: Call it a hunch.
CONSTANCE: A hunch?
DOCTOR: About why this place was built.
YOUNG PERCY: The stone circle?
DOCTOR: I’d assumed it was just a marker, for an... instrument beneath the Earth... but what if it’s more than that?

DOCTOR: A control panel. (BEAT) Alright, Percy, let’s lay out your... doppelganger on one of the altar stones.
PERCY: Which one?

CONSTANCE: This is just guesswork?
DOCTOR: Well, I have a fifty percent chance of being right.
CONSTANCE: Which means you have a fifty percent chance of being wrong!
YOUNG PERCY: What are you two talking about?
DOCTOR: This... ‘temple’ was built for a specific purpose.
DOCTOR: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 96

OLD PERCY: (NARRATION)

CROSS TO: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 97
FLIP: (READING) At first, nothing happened. Then a strange fatigue came over me and I closed my eyes. I must have fallen asleep, for how long I could not say...
CROSS BACK TO: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 98
OLD PERCY: (NARRATION) But when I opened my eyes again, I was lying on the other altar, and feeling more alive than I had ever felt before.
YOUNG PERCY: (WAKING) What happened?

DOCTOR: You didn’t. Look.
OLD PERCY: (NARRATION)
OLD PERCY: I looked across — to see myself lying on the other altar. Or rather, my body, in what appeared to be a state of unconsciousness. And a state of undress - as I was now wearing its uniform.
YOUNG PERCY: But I don’t — how?
CONSTANCE: Your mind moved across. You fell asleep in one body — and woke up in a new one.
DOCTOR: I, ahem, took the liberty of transferring your accoutrements. Don’t worry. Leading Wren Clarke averted her eyes.
YOUNG PERCY: Sorry, my ‘new’ body? You mean, the one from inside the tree?
DOCTOR: Yes. It turns out my hunch was correct.
YOUNG PERCY: I’m very happy for you. Would you mind explaining it to us lesser mortals?
WEBSTER: (DISTANT) Over there! There’s someone in the stone circle!
CONSTANCE: (OVER THIS) Doctor.
CONSTANCE: DW #233: STATIC by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 99
DOCTOR: I see them. Percy, can you stand?
YOUNG PERCY: (GETTING UP) Yeah, course, why?

YOUNG PERCY: Right, yeah.
CONSTANCE: What about the other one, the ‘original’?

CONSTANCE: But he — it — is still alive. It’s still breathing.

OLD PERCY: (NARRATION)
OLD PERCY: I watched from hiding as the soldiers entered the stone circle and surrounded my old body, keeping their rifles raised as though they were expecting it to make a break for it at any second.

WEBSTER: (CONSIDERS, THEN) Alright, men, take him away!
SOLDIERS: Yes, sir!

OLD PERCY: (NARRATION)
OLD PERCY: I lifted my head, to see that the stone circle was enclosed in an impenetrable fog. The soldiers stepped back in fear as a curtain of mist flowed into the circle and enveloped the body on the altar. A moment later, the body was gone, and the fog faded away to nothing.

DOCTOR: Precisely. This place isn’t here to bring back the dead for a farewell chat. It’s to enable them to cheat death itself! (BEAT) Alright, Percy. You can come out now!

FLIP: Hiya babes.

CONSTANCE: And then I could see them. They were just shapes in the mist at first, shadows, but as they walked towards us, I could make out their green-brown uniforms. Some of them still had their flying goggles on. A couple were wearing orange life-jackets. And they were all so young, in their twenties, little more than boys...

CONSTANCE: . They were all speaking like their voices were coming through
CONSTANCE: radios.
